title: Oprah Winfrey takes stake in Weight Watchers as company refocuses on wellness | Entertainment News
text:
Shares of Weight Watchers International Inc. soared Monday morning on news that Oprah Winfrey is taking a 10 percent stake in the company and joining the firm's board of directors.
The company's stock was up $5.86, a whopping 86.3 percent, to $12.65 in early morning trading.
"Weight Watchers has given me the tools to begin to make the lasting shift that I and so many of us who are struggling with weight have longed for," said Winfrey, who has publicly battled weight gain for decades. "I believe in the program so much I decided to invest in the company and partner in its evolution."
The deal comes as Weight Watchers faces tough competition from new diet and fitness apps, as well as a growing trend away from calorie counting toward overall wellness.
As part of a five-year agreement, Winfrey gave Weight Watchers permission to use her name, image and endorsement on its products and programs.
Winfrey is paying about $43.2 million for 6.4 million shares of Weight Watchers at a price of $6.79 each. Winfrey also has the option to acquire an additional 5 percent of shares.
"We believe that her remarkable ability to connect and inspire people to realize their full potential is uniquely complementary to our powerful community," Jim Chambers, Weight Watchers chief executive, said in a statement.
Winfrey's appointment increases the Weight Watchers board of directors from nine to 10. Her term will expire in 2018.
In an August call with analysts, the company recognized that customers wanted to lose weight through a "more holistic mindset" involving healthier eating, fitness and emotional strength, and said it would develop a new market campaign to reflect this.
"We are expanding our purpose from focusing on weight loss alone to more broadly helping people lead a healthier, happier life," Chambers said in the statement announcing Winfrey's involvement.
